titleStmt.title: Full-duplex Non-orthogonal Multiple Access in Cooperative Relay Sharing for 5G Systems

affiliation.orgName: Department of Electrical and Electronic Engineering

analytic.title: Full-duplex Non-orthogonal Multiple Access in Cooperative Relay Sharing for 5G Systems

Citation information: DOI 10.1109/TVT.2018.2799939, IEEE Transactions on Vehicular Technology

application.desc: GROBID - A machine learning software for extracting information from scholarly documents

div.p: In this paper, a full-duplex (FD) non-orthogonal multiple access (NOMA) scheme for a cooperative relay sharing network (termed as FD-NOMA-RS) is presented, in which two source-destination pairs share a dedicated FD relay FD-R. Following the principle of uplink NOMA, both sources transmit their symbols to FD-R, forming a NOMA pair, by depending on their channel conditions with respect to FD-R. The FD-R then decodes these symbols and simultaneously transmits a superimposed composite signal to the destinations with a processing delay τ according to the principle of downlink NOMA. The ergodic sum capacity, outage probability and outage sum capacity of FD-NOMA-RS are investigated comprehensively along with analytical derivations, considering both perfect and imperfect interference cancellation. A simulation is conducted to corroborate the correctness of the analysis presented here. Moreover, the effectiveness of FD-NOMA-RS is demonstrated through analysis and simulation and then compared with that of its counterpart, the half-duplex system.

div.head: I. INTRODUCTION
div.p: A S a possible candidate technique to radio access of the fifth-generation (5G) wireless networks, non-orthogonal multiple access (NOMA) has garnered considerable interest from both industry and academia in their attempt to significantly boost system's spectral efficiency and serve a large number of users [1], [2]. In NOMA-based systems, the users are served simultaneously by the same code at the same frequency, but at different power levels. Successive interference cancellation (SIC) [1] or multilevel decoding, based on gray labeling [3], or parallel/hybrid interference cancellation [4] technique, can be carried out at the receiver side to separate superimposed messages, transmitted by the source.

Cooperative relaying has proved to be one the most effective ways to improve system capacity and/or reliability of a wireless network, where dedicated relays or users cooperate [5]. To further improve the spectral efficiency of a wireless network, cooperative NOMA [6]- [20] was introduced recently. It has been shown that NOMA can achieve better spectral efficiency than conventional multiple access (OMA), such as timedivision multiple access or frequency-division multiple access. The concept of user cooperation in NOMA-based system was first proposed in [6] to exploit spatial diversity, where the users, having better channel status, work as relays for the users, having worse channel status. Dedicated half-duplex (HD)/fullduplex (FD) relay was subsequently incorporated [7]- [20] into NOMA-based system to facilitate transmission between NOMA transmitter and receiver.

Cooperative downlink NOMA, utilizing HD decode-andforward (DF) and amplify-and-forward (AF) relay, were studied in [7]- [12] and [13]- [17], respectively. A cooperative relaying system (CRS), using NOMA (referred to as CRS-NOMA hereafter) for spatially multiplexed transmission, was proposed in [7], wherein it was shown that CRS-NOMA [7] can attain better spectral efficiency than conventional CRS, such as traditional DF, when signal-to-noise ratio (SNR) ρ is higher and mean channel gain of source (S)-to-relay (R) link is better than those of S-to-destination (D) and R-to-D links. A novel detection scheme for CRS-NOMA exploiting both maximal-ratio combining (MRC) and SIC at the receiver, was studied in [8], whereas a coordinated direct and relay transmission technique for NOMA was proposed in [9]. The methods proposed in both [8] and [9] outperformed the method proposed in [7], in terms of ergodic sum capacity (ESC). The outage probability (OP) and outage capacity (OC) of CRS-NOMA, over slow fading channels, were investigated in [10], wherein it was shown that CRS-NOMA can outperform noncooperative NOMA, in terms of OP. The integration of spacetime block coding into NOMA was exploited for CRS in [11], wherein it was pointed out that the proposed scheme can outperform [7], [8] and TDF [5], in terms of ESC and OP, respectively. Moreover, the computational complexity of a NOMA-based system, in terms of its complex operations (e.g., SIC, MRC), was first discussed in [11]. In [12], the performance of CRS-NOMA was studied under a multi-relay scenario and a two-stage relay selection scheme proposed.

The performance of downlink CRS-NOMA was studied in [13]- [15], wherein a base station (BS) communicates with a set of M (M => 2) mobile users, who form a cluster and utilize an AF relay. Also, the superiority of the proposed protocol over OMA was validated through analysis and simulation. It was shown that CRS-NOMA can achieve superior coding gain to that of OMA, in terms of OP, the diversity order being the same in both [16]. The application of CRS-NOMA with fixed gain AF relaying was studied in [17] by considering two scenarios, one with AF relay and the other without. In [18], a NOMA-based hybrid DF and AF scheme was studied to improve system capacity under multi-relay scenario. It is to be noted that all the above cited works [6]- [18] adopted HD cooperation mechanism for their study.

In [19], it was demonstrated that the performance of CRS-NOMA can be improved by using an FD relay in place of HD relay, and by considering a scenario similar to that in [9]. It was also shown that the proposed FD CRS-NOMA can, no doubt, yield better performance, in terms of ESC and OP under perfect self-interference cancellation, but that performance gain depends very much on residual self-interference under imperfect self-interference cancellation. To improve OP of a NOMA-weak user, an FD device-to-device aided NOMA scheme was studied in [20] by considering a scenario similar to that in [6], wherein a NOMA-strong user acted as an FD relay for a NOMA-weak user.

Sharing cooperative relay by multiple users, to reduce network deployment cost, is another interesting topic of research. In [21], [22], the performance of cognitive radio networks was studied, wherein a dedicated relay was shared by both primary and secondary users. The application of NOMA to cooperative relay sharing network (referred to as HD-NOMA-RS) was first studied recently in [23], for which a dedicated HD relay was shared by two S-D pairs. The ESC of the proposed network was derived analytically under both perfect and imperfect SIC. A cooperative relay sharing network, using OMA (referred to as HD-OMA-RS), was also devised in [23]. The superiority of HD-NOMA-RS to HD-OMA-RS, in terms of ESC, was also validated through analysis and simulation.

Motivated by the findings in [23], an FD protocol for a cooperative relay sharing network is investigated in this paper to overcome the spectral efficiency loss in a HD protocol (e.g., [23]). The following are the principal contributions of this paper:

1) An FD protocol, for a cooperative relay sharing network (termed as FD-NOMA-RS), is proposed and investigated, wherein two sources can communicate simultaneously with their corresponding destinations via an FD relay. 2) Analytical derivations of ESC, OP, and outage sum capacity (OSC) of FD-NOMA-RS are provided for both perfect and imperfect interference cancellation (IC) scenarios. The correctness of the analytical results is corroborated by simulation.

3) The proposed protocol is compared with HD-NOMA-RS [23] and HD-OMA-RS [23], in terms of ESC and OP. It is to be noted that only ESC was investigated in [23]. Therefore, to provide a more extensive performance comparison with FD-NOMA-RS, OPs of HD-NOMA-RS and HD-OMA-RS are also analytically derived in this paper. In particular, it is demonstrated that FD-NOMA-RS can achieve outstanding performance gains compared to HD-NOMA-RS. On the contrary, it is shown that the performance gains over HD-OMA-RS depend on power allocation factors, SNR range, and level of residual interference. The remainder of the paper is organized as follows: The system architecture and a detailed protocol description of the proposed FD-NOMA-RS are provided in Section II. Comprehensive performance analysis in terms of ESC, OP and OSC along with analytical derivations is presented in Sections III, IV, and V, respectively. The simulations conducted for validating the correctness of the analysis are demonstrated in Section VI, and finally in Section VII, the conclusion from this study is drawn along with suggestions for future research.

div.head: II. NETWORK ARCHITECTURE AND PROTOCOL DESCRIPTIONS
div.p: Let it be assumed a scenario, where a group of transmitters considered as sources distributed in a place wants to communicate with their corresponding destinations distributed in another place. The direct links between sources and destinations are ignored because of very poor channel conditions and/or physical obstructions [12], [15], [22], [23]. In such a situation, a cooperative relay can be used in-between sources and destinations to perform data communication. Now, the question is: how do multiple sources communicate with their corresponding destinations via a common relay. To answer this crucial question, the following system and channel models are proposed in this study.

div.head: A. System and Channel Models
div.p: In the proposed system model, shown in Fig. 1, a cooperative network scenario is considered, where a common FD relay FD-R employing DF scheme can be shared by two S-D pairs, G 1 ={S 1 , D 1 } and G 2 ={S 2 , D 2 }, in the same frequency band, using NOMA. In FD-NOMA-RS, S 1 and S 2 are allowed to communicate with their corresponding destinations, D 1 and D 2 , simultaneously. It should be mentioned that the placement of nodes in Fig. 1 is decided, considering the two following points: (i) S 1 and S 2 can form a NOMA pair [24] to transmit simultaneously to FD-R, following the principle of uplink NOMA [23], [25], and FD-R can concurrently transmit a superimposed composite signal, consisting of the decoded symbols, transmitted by sources to D 1 and D 2 , following the principle of downlink NOMA [7]- [11], [23]; (ii) SIC can be carried out for the same S-D pair in both uplink and downlink, and thus the total system capacity can be maximized [23].

Let it be assumed that the channel over each link is subjected to Rayleigh flat fading plus additive white Gaussian noise. The complex channel coefficients for the links S 1 →FD-R, FD-R→D 1 , S 2 →FD-R, and FD-R→D 2 are represented by
div.formula: h 1,ul ∼ CN(0, λ 1,ul = d -v 1,ul ), h 1,dl ∼ CN(0, λ 1,dl = d -v 1,dl ), h 2,ul ∼ CN(0, λ 2,ul = d -v
div.p: 2,ul ), and h 2,dl ∼ CN(0, λ 2,dl = d -v 2,dl ) with zero mean and variances of λ 1,ul , λ 1,dl , λ 2,ul , and λ 2,ul , respectively. The path loss exponent is expressed by v and d 1,ul , d 1,dl , d 2,ul , and d 2,dl denote the distance in meters from S 1 to FD-R, FD-R to D 1 , S 2 to FD-R, and FD-R to D 2 , respectively. Therefore, the channel gains |h 1,ul | 2 , |h 1,dl | 2 , |h 2,ul | 2 , and |h 2,dl | 2 can be considered exponentially distributed random variables with mean values or scale parameters λ 1,ul , λ 1,dl , λ 2,ul , and λ 2,ul , respectively [11], [26], [27]. It is assumed that the residual self-interference channel h r,r is free from fading [20]. Without loss of generality, the channels are arranged in the ordered
div.formula: |h 1,ul | 2 > |h 2,ul | 2 and |h 2,dl | 2 > |h 1,dl | 2 because it is assumed that d 1,ul < d 2,ul and d 2,dl < d 1,dl . Though d 1,ul < d 2,ul and d 2,dl < d 1,dl may not guarantee |h 1,ul | 2 > |h 2,ul | 2 and |h 2,dl | 2 > |h 1,dl | 2 ,
div.p: it is a simple but effective strategy under statistical channel state information [28], [29], and therefore we focus on this specific scheme to facilitate the performance analysis of the proposed system. The signal-to-interferenceplus-noise ratio (SINR) computation along with the data transmission policy of FD-NOMA-RS is described in the following subsection.

div.head: B. Signal-to-interference-plus-noise ratio (SINR) Model
div.p: Following the principle of uplink NOMA, during the k th (k=1,2,3...) time slot, both S 1 and S 2 transmit symbols s 1 and s 2 simultaneously with powers θ 1 P t and θ 2 P t , respectively, where θ 1 and θ 2 are the power allocation coefficients and P t is the total transmit power of sources. Concurrently, FD-R transmits the superimposed composite signal Z = √ θ 3 P r s 1 + √ θ 4 P r s 2 to D 1 and D 2 with a processing delay τ following the principle of downlink NOMA, where θ 3 , θ 4 are the power allocation coefficients, P r is the total transmit power of FD-R, and s 1 , s 2 are the regenerated data symbols at FD-R. It is to be noted that θ 1 + θ 2 = 1 and θ 3 + θ 4 = 1 are the total transmission power requirement constraints that need to be satisfied for many practical scenarios [25]. By virtue of its acting as an FD mode, FD-R can transmit simultaneously with S 1 and S 2 .

According to uplink NOMA, FD-R first decodes s 1 with better channel condition by treating s 2 , having worse channel condition, as noise. SIC is then carried out at FD-R to obtain symbol s 2 . Therefore, the SINRs received at FD-R, associated with s 1 and s 2 , are respectively given by
div.formula: γ t 1 s 1 = θ 1 ρ s |h 1,ul | 2 θ 2 ρ s |h 2,ul | 2 + I s + 1 ,(1)
γ t 1 s 2 = θ 2 ρ s |h 2,ul | 2 θ 1 ρ s | ḡ1,ul | 2 + I s + 1 ,(2)
div.p: where ρ s P t σ 2 , ḡ1,ul ∼ CN(0, κ 1 λ 1,ul ), and σ 2 is noise variance. The parameter I s represents residual self-interference, which can be considered a constant as in [20] for simplicity of analysis. Moreover, the level of residual interference, because of SIC imperfection at FD-R, is denoted by κ 1 (0 ≤ κ 1 ≤ 1). As a particular case, κ 1 = 0 and κ 1 = 1 represent perfect SIC and no SIC, respectively.
On the contrary, according to the principle of downlink NOMA, D 1 decodes s 1 by treating s 2 as noise. Therefore, the SINR received at D 1 is given by
div.formula: γ t 2 s 1 = θ 3 ρ r |h 1,dl | 2 θ 4 ρ r |h 1,dl | 2 + 1 .(3)
div.p: Conversely, D 2 first decodes high powered symbol s 1 by treating own low powered symbol s 2 as noise, and then, SIC is carried out at D 2 to obtain s 2 . Therefore, the SINRs received at D 2 , associated with s 1 and s 2 , are given by
div.formula: γ t 2 s 1 →s 2 = θ 3 ρ r |h 2,dl | 2 θ 4 ρ r |h 2,dl | 2 + 1 ,(4)
γ t 2 s 2 = θ 4 ρ r |h 2,dl | 2 θ 3 ρ r | ḡ2,dl | 2 + 1 ,(5)
div.p: where ρ r P r σ 2 , ḡ2,dl ∼ CN(0, κ 2 λ 2,dl ), and γ t 2 s 1 →s 2 represents the SINR required at D 2 to decode symbol s 1 . The level of residual interference at D 2 because of SIC imperfection is denoted by κ 2 , which indicates similar behavior to κ 1 .

div.head: III. ERGODIC CAPACITY ANALYSIS
div.p: In this section, ESC of FD-NOMA-RS is investigated, along with analytical derivations, over an independent Rayleigh fading channel. To make this presentation self-contained, ESC of HD-NOMA-RS [23] and HD-OMA-RS [23] is also discussed briefly in subsection B.
A. Proposed FD-NOMA-RS 1) Ergodic Capacity of G 1 : By using (1), (3), and (4), the achievable capacity of G 1 is obtained as
div.formula: C 1 = log 2 (1 + min(γ t 1 s 1 , γ t 2 s 1 , γ t 2 s 1 →s 2 )).(6)
div.p: Let
div.formula: U γ t 1 s 1 = θ 1 ρ s |h 1,ul | 2 θ 2 ρ s |h 2,ul | 2 +I s +1 , V γ t 2 s 1 = θ 3 ρ r |h 1,dl | 2 θ 4 ρ r |h 1,dl | 2 +1 , W γ t 2 s 1 →s 2 = θ 3 ρ r |h 2,dl | 2 θ 4 ρ r |h 2,dl | 2 +1
div.p: and X = min(U,V,W ). The cumulative distribution function (CDF) of U, V , and W can be respectively written as
div.formula: F U (u) =1 - a a + bu e -uIc a ,(7)
div.p: where a = θ 1 ρ s λ 1,ul , b = θ 2 ρ s λ 2,ul , I c = I s + 1, c = ρ r λ 1,dl , and d = ρ r λ 2,dl . Now, by using ( 7), ( 8), ( 9) and the CDF of the minimum of two exponential distributed random variables, the CDF of X can be written as
div.formula: F X (x) =1 - a a + bx e -xIc a - x (θ 3 -θ 4 x)c - x (θ 3 -θ 4 x)d . (10

) By using ∞ 0 log 2 (1 + x) f X (x)dx = 1 ln 2 ∞ 0 1-F X (x) 1+x dx, ergodic capacity (EC) of G 1 is therefore calculated as C1 = log 2 e ∞ 0 a(1 + x) -1 a + bx e -xIc a - x (θ 3 -θ 4 x)c - x (θ 3 -θ 4 x)d dx. (11
div.p: The solution of equations, such as (11) do not admit a closed-form [9], [19], [23]. Hence, at high ρ s and ρ r , X = min(U,V,W ) can be written as X min(
div.formula: θ 1 ρ s |h 1,ul | 2 θ 2 ρ s |h 2,ul | 2 +I s +1 , θ 3 ρ r |h 1,dl | 2 θ 4 ρ r |h 1,dl | 2 +1 , θ 3 ρ r |h 2,dl | 2 θ 4 ρ r |h 2,dl | 2 +1 ) ≈ min( θ 1 |h 1,ul | 2 θ 2 |h 2,ul | 2 , θ 3 θ 4 ) ≈ min(Y, θ 3 θ 4 ).
div.p: The probability density function of Y can be written as in [30], [31]
div.formula: f y (y) = θ 1 θ 2 λ 1,ul λ 2,ul (θ 1 λ 1,ul + θ 2 λ 2,ul y) 2 . (12
div.p: So, the approximate EC of G 1 can be computed as [9, eq. ( 15)]
div.formula: C FD 1 ∼ ∞ θ 3 θ 4 log 2 (1 + θ 3 θ 4 ) + θ 3 θ 4 0 log 2 (1 + y) f Y (y)dy ∼ θ 1 λ 1,ul log 2 e θ 1 λ 1,ul -θ 2 λ 2,ul ln 1 + θ 3 θ 4 -ln θ 1 λ 1,ul θ 2 λ 2,ul + θ 3 θ 4 + ln θ 1 λ 1,ul θ 2 λ 2,ul ∼ θ 1 λ 1,ul log 2 e θ 1 λ 1,ul -θ 2 λ 2,ul ln θ 1 λ 1,ul (θ 3 + θ 4 ) θ 1 θ 4 λ 1,ul + θ 2 θ 3 λ 2,ul .(13)
div.p: 2) Ergodic Capacity of G 2 : By using ( 2) and ( 5), the achievable capacity of G 2 is obtained as
div.formula: C 2 = log 2 (1 + min(γ t 1 s 2 , γ t 2 s 2 )).(14)
div.p: Let Z min(γ
div.formula: t 1 s 2 , γ t 2 s 2 ) = min( θ 2 ρ s |h 2,ul | 2 θ 1 ρ s | ḡ1,ul | 2 +I s +1 , θ 4 ρ r |h 2,dl | 2 θ 3 ρ r | ḡ2,dl | 2 +1
div.p: ). By using (7) and the CDF of the minimum of two exponential distributed random variables, the CDF of Z can be written as
div.formula: F Z (z) =1 - ik (i + jz)(k + lz) e -mz ,(15)
div.p: where i = θ 2 λ 2,ul , j = θ 1 κ 1 λ 1,ul , k = θ 4 λ 2,dl , l = θ 3 κ 2 λ 2,dl , and m =
div.formula: I c θ 2 ρ s λ 2,ul + 1 θ 4 ρ r λ 2,dl . The exact EC of G 2 is therefore computed as C2 = log 2 e ∞ 0 ik(1 + z) -1 (i + jz)(k + lz) e -mz dz.(16)
div.p: By using [23, eq. ( 22)], ( 16) can be simplified as
div.formula: C2 =P log 2 e -Q exp(m) Ei(-m) + R exp(mn) Ei(-mn) +(Q -R) exp(mo) Ei(-mo) ,(17)
div.p: where
div.formula: P = i i-j , Q = k k-l , R = k k-ln , n = i j , o = k l
div.p: , and Ei(.) is the exponential integral function [32, eq. (8.211.1)]. Moreover, the approximate EC of G 2 at high ρ s and ρ r can be written as in [23, eq. (23)]
div.formula: C FD 2 ∼ P log 2 e Qm(o -1) + Rm(n -o) E c + ln m + ln o(om + 1)(Q -R) + R(1 + mn) ln n ,(18)
div.p: where E c is a mathematical constant, called as Euler's constant, whose numerical value is 0.577215. . . [32]. Now, the perfect IC i.e., κ 1 = κ 2 = 0 and
div.formula: I s = 0 is considered. It is assumed that Z min(γ t 1 s 2 , γ t 2 s 2 ) = min(θ 2 ρ s |h 2,ul | 2 , θ 4 ρ r |h 2,dl | 2 )
div.p: . By using the CDF of Z and
div.formula: ∞ 0 log 2 (1 + x) f X (x)dx = 1 ln 2 ∞ 0 1-F X (x)
div.p: 1+x dx, the exact and approximate EC of G 2 are therefore respectively written as
div.formula: C2,p = log 2 e ∞ 0 e -Sz 1 + z dz = -(log 2 e)e S Ei(-S),(19)
C FD 2,p ∼ -log 2 e(1 + S)(E c + ln S),(20)
div.p: where S =
div.formula: 1 θ 2 ρ s λ 2,ul + 1 θ 4 ρ r λ 2,dl.
div.p: 3) Ergodic Sum Capacity of FD-NOMA-RS: By using ( 6) and ( 14), ESC of FD-NOMA-RS is obtained as
div.formula: C FD sum = E{C 1 } + E{C 2 }, (21
div.p: where E is the expectation operator.

div.head: B. Recent Schemes Revisited
div.p: In HD-NOMA-RS [23], two sources communicate with their corresponding destinations in parallel over the same frequency band via a common HD relay. Using [23, eqs. (6 & 13)], ESC of HD-NOMA-RS is given as
div.formula: C HD sum = E 1 2 log 2 (1 + min(γ t 1 s 1 ,N , γ t 2 s 1 ,N , γ t 2 s 1 →s 2 ,N )) + E 1 2 log 2 (1 + min(γ t 1 s 2 ,N , γ t 2 s 2 ,N )) = C HD 1 +C HD 2 ,(22)
div.p: where
div.formula: γ t 1 s 1 ,N = θ 1 ρ s |h 1,ul | 2 θ 2 ρ s |h 2,ul | 2 +1 , γ t 2 s 1 ,N = θ 3 ρ r |h 1,dl | 2 θ 4 ρ r |h 1,dl | 2 +1 , γ t 2 s 1 →s 2 ,N = θ 3 ρ r |h 2,dl | 2 θ 4 ρ r |h 2,dl | 2 +1 , γ t 1 s 2 ,N = θ 2 ρ s |h 2,ul | 2 θ 1 ρ s | ḡ1,ul | 2 +1
div.p: , and
div.formula: γ t 2 s 2 ,N = θ 4 ρ r |h 2,dl | 2 θ 3 ρ r | ḡ2,dl | 2 +1
div.p: . On the contrary, in HD-OMA-RS [23], two sources communicate with their corresponding destinations in parallel over different frequency bands via a common HD relay. The ESC of HD-OMA-RS is given as in [23, eq. ( 28)]
div.formula: C HD OMA = E 1 2 β w log 2 (1 + min(γ t 1 s 1 ,O , γ t 2 s 1 ,O )) + E 1 2 (1 -β w ) log 2 (1 + min(γ t 1 s 2 ,O , γ t 2 s 2 ,O )) =C HD 1,OMA +C HD 2,OMA ,(23)
div.p: where
div.formula: γ t 1 s 1 ,O = P 1 ρ s |h 1,ul | 2 β w , γ t 2 s 1 ,O = P 1 ρ r |h 1,dl | 2 β w , γ t 1 s 2 ,O = P 2 ρ s |h 2,ul | 2 (1-β w ) , γ t 2 s 2 ,O = P 2 ρ r |h 2,dl | 2
div.p: (1-β w ) , P 1 and P 2 are the power allocation factors, and β w (0 ≤ β w ≤ 1) denotes the total bandwidth of the system.

div.head: IV. OUTAGE PROBABILITY ANALYSIS
div.p: In this section, OP of FD-NOMA-RS is investigated along with analytical derivations over an independent Rayleigh fading channel. It should be mentioned that OP of HD-NOMA-RS and HD-OMA-RS is not provided in [23]; therefore, to facilitate its comparison with that of FD-NOMA-RS, it is formulated in subsection B.

div.head: A. Proposed FD-NOMA-RS
div.p: According to the required quality of service, C O 1 and C O 2 are assumed to be the predefined target rate thresholds of G 1 and G 2 , respectively. The exact OP of G 1 and G 2 is computed in the following subsections.

div.head: 1) Outage Probability of G 1 :
div.p: The exact OP of G 1 can be written as
div.formula: P FD O,1 = 1 -P r γ t 1 s 1 > 2 C O 1 -1 ∩ γ t 2 s 1 > 2 C O 1 -1 = 1 -P r γ t 1 s 1 > 2 C O 1 -1 × P r γ t 2 s 1 > 2 C O 1 -1 = 1 - θ 1 ρ s λ 1,ul θ 1 ρ s λ 1,ul + θ 2 ρ s λ 2,ul R t e -R t Ic θ 1 ρsλ 1,ul - R t (θ 3 -θ 4 R t )ρr λ 1,dl ,(24)
div.p: where R t = 2 C O 1 -1, R t R t +1 < θ 3 < 1. Now, by substituting I s =0 in (24), the exact OP of G 1 under perfect IC can be obtained as
div.formula: P FD O,1,p =1 - θ 1 λ 1,ul θ 1 λ 1,ul + θ 2 λ 2,ul R t e - R t θ 1 ρsλ 1,ul - R t (θ 3 -θ 4 R t )ρr λ 1,dl . (25)
div.p: 2) Outage Probability of G 2 : The exact OP of G 2 can be written as
div.formula: P FD O,2 =1 -P r γ t 1 s 2 > 2 C O 2 -1 ∩ γ t 2 s 2 > 2 C O 2 -1 ∩ γ t 2 s 1 →s 2 > 2 C O 1 -1 =1 -P r γ t 1 s 2 > 2 C O 2 -1 × P r γ t 2 s 2 > 2 C O 2 -1 × P r γ t 2 s 1 →s 2 > 2 C O 1 -1 =1 - θ 2 θ 4 λ 2,ul λ 2,dl (θ 2 λ 2,ul + θ 1 κ 1 λ 1,ul Rt )(θ 4 λ 2,dl + θ 3 κ 2 λ 2,dl Rt ) × e -Rt Ic θ 2 ρsλ 2,ul - Rt θ 4 ρr λ 2,dl - R t (θ 3 -θ 4 R t )ρr λ 2,dl ,(26)
div.p: where Rt = 2 C O 2 -1. Now, by substituting κ 1 = κ 2 = I s =0 in (26), the exact OP of G 2 under perfect IC can be obtained as
div.formula: P FD O,2, p =1 - θ 2 θ 4 λ 2,ul λ 2,dl θ 2 λ 2,ul θ 4 λ 2,dl e - Rt θ 2 ρsλ 2,ul - Rt θ 4 ρr λ 2,dl - R t (θ 3 -θ 4 R t )ρr λ 2,dl =1 -e - Rt θ 2 ρsλ 2,ul - Rt θ 4 ρr λ 2,dl - R t (θ 3 -θ 4 R )ρr λ 2,dl .(27)

div.head: B. Outage Probability of HD-NOMA-RS and HD-OMA-RS
div.p: Similar to ( 24) and ( 26), OPs of G 1 and G 2 in HD-NOMA-RS are respectively given by
div.formula: P HD O,1 = 1 -P r γ t 1 s 1 ,N > R 1 t P r γ t 2 s 1 ,N > R 1 t = 1 - θ 1 λ 1,ul θ 1 λ 1,ul + θ 2 λ 2,ul R 1 t e - R 1 t θ 1 ρsλ 1,ul - R 1 t (θ 3 -θ 4 R 1 t )ρr λ 1,dl ,(28)

P HD O,2 = 1 -P r γ t 1 s 2 ,N > R 2 t P r γ t 2 s 2 ,N > R 2 t P r γ t 2 s 1 →s 2 ,N > R 1 t =1 - θ 2 θ 4 λ 2,ul λ 2,dl (θ 2 λ 2,ul + θ 1 κ 1 λ 1,ul R 2 t )(θ 4 λ 2,dl + θ 3 κ 2 λ 2,dl R 2 t ) × e - R 2 t θ 2 ρsλ 2,ul - R 2 t θ 4 ρr λ 2,dl - R 1 t (θ 3 -θ 4 R 1 t )ρr λ 2,dl ,(29)
div.p: where 29), the exact OP of G 2 under perfect IC can be obtained as
div.formula: R 1 t = 2 2C O 1 -1, R 2 t = 2 2C O 2 -1, and R 1 t R 1 t +1 < θ 3 < 1. Now, by substituting κ 1 = κ 2 =0 in (
P HD O,2,p =1 -e - R 2 t θ 2 ρsλ 2,ul - R 2 t θ 4 ρr λ 2,dl - R 1 t (θ 3 -θ 4 R 1 t )ρr λ 2,dl .(30)
div.p: Moreover, OPs of G 1 and G 2 in HD-OMA-RS are respectively given by
div.formula: P OMA O,1 =1 -P r γ t 1 s 1 ,O > R 1 O P r γ t 2 s 1 ,O > R 1 O =1 -e - βwR 1 O P 1 ρsλ 1,ul - βwR 1 O P 1 ρr λ 1,dl ,(31)
P OMA O,2 =1 -P r γ t 1 s 2 ,O > R 2 O P r γ t 2 s 2 ,O > R 2 O =1 -e - (1-βw)R 2 O P 2 ρsλ 2,ul - (1-βw)R 2 O P 2 ρr λ 2,dl ,(32)
div.p: where
div.formula: R 1 O = 2 2C O 1 βw -1 and R 2 O = 2 2C O 2 1-βw -1.

div.head: V. OUTAGE CAPACITY ANALYSIS
div.p: In this section, the OSC of the proposed FD-NOMA-RS is investigated, including its analytical derivation. The OC is defined as the data rate that can be achieved if an outage is allowed to the system with probability ε. By using [33, eq. (2.68)], OC of G 1 and G 2 can be computed from their corresponding OP. It is to be noted that getting the exact OC of G 1 and G 2 from their corresponding OP is not easy. Therefore, in the following subsections, it is attempted to compute the approximate OC.

div.head: A. Outage Capacity of G 1
div.p: Using e x ≈ 1 + x at high ρ s and ρ r , OC C O 1 of G 1 , with specified OP ε 1 can be computed from (24) as
div.formula: ε 1 =1 - Aρ s Aρ s + Bρ s R t 1 - R t I c Aρ s - R t (θ 3 -θ 4 R t )Dρ r = R t Dρ s ρ r (A + BR t )(θ 3 -θ 4 R t ) BDρ s ρ r (θ 3 -θ 4 R t ) + DI c ρ r (θ 3 -θ 4 R t ) + Aρ s ,(33)
div.p: where
div.formula: A = θ 1 λ 1,ul , B = θ 2 λ 2,ul , C = θ 3 -θ 4 R t , and D = λ 1,dl .
div.p: After some algebraic simplifications, (33) can be written as
div.formula: (R t ) 2 BDθ 4 ρ s ρ r (1 -ε 1 ) + Dρ r I c θ 4 +R t -ADθ 4 ρ s ρ r ε 1 +BDθ 3 ρ s ρ r (ε 1 -1) -DI c θ 3 ρ r -Aρ s +ADθ 3 ρ s ρ r ε 1 = 0. (34
div.p: Let it be assumed that α = BDθ 4 ρ s ρ r (1
div.formula: -ε 1 ) + Dρ r I c θ 4 , β = -ADθ 4 ρ s ρ r ε 1 + BDθ 3 ρ s ρ r (ε 1 -1) -DI c θ 3 ρ r -Aρ s and χ = ADθ 3 ρ s ρ r ε 1 .
div.p: Then, (34) can be expressed as
Solving (35) for R t and taking the feasible root, it is obtained as
div.formula: R t = -β -β 2 -4α χ 2α 2 C O 1 -1 = -β -β 2 -4α χ 2α C O 1 = log 2 1 + -β -β 2 -4α χ 2α . (36
div.p: Now, by substituting I s =0 in (36), OC of G 1 under perfect IC can be obtained.

div.head: B. Outage Capacity of G 2
div.p: Using e x ≈ 1 + x at high ρ s and ρ r , OC C O 2 of G 2 , with specified OP ε 2 can be computed from ( 26) as
div.formula: ε 2 =1 - ik (i + j Rt )(k + l Rt ) 1 - Rt I c iρ s - Rt kρ r , (37
conditioned on γ t 2 s 1 →s 2 > 2 C O 1 -1, where i = θ 2 λ 2,ul , j = θ 1 κ 1 λ 1,ul , k = θ 4 λ 2,
div.p: dl , and l = θ 3 κ 2 λ 2,dl . After some algebraic simplifications, (37) can be written as
div.formula: ( Rt ) 2 jlρ s ρ r (ε 2 -1) + Rt ρ s ρ r (il + jk)(ε 2 -1) -kI c ρ r -iρ s + ikρ s ρ r ε 2 = 0. (38
div.p: Let it be assumed that
div.formula: E = jlρ s ρ r (ε 2 -1), F = ρ s ρ r (il + jk)(ε 2 -1) -kI c ρ r -iρ s and G = ikρ s ρ r ε 2 .
div.p: Then, (38) can be expressed as
Solving (39) for Rt and taking the feasible root, it is obtained as
Now, the perfect IC i.e., κ 1 = κ 2 = 0 and I s = 0, is investigated. Therefore, OC of G 2 under perfect IC is computed as
div.formula: ε 2,p =1 -1 - Rt iρ s - Rt kρ r = Rt iρ s + Rt kρ r Rt = ikρ s ρ r ε 2,p iρ s + kρ r C O 2 = log 2 1 + ikρ s ρ r ε 2,p iρ s + kρ r .(41)
div.p: C. Outage Sum Capacity of FD-NOMA-RS Using (36) and ( 40)/(41), OSC of FD-NOMA-RS is obtained as
div.formula: C FD O,sum = C O 1 +C O 2 . (42

div.head: VI. NUMERICAL RESULTS AND DISCUSSION
div.p: To demonstrate the effectiveness of FD-NOMA-RS, the analytical (Anl.) results, together with Monte Carlo simulations (Sim.), in terms of ESC, OP, and OSC are presented in this section. The simulation parameters, unless otherwise specified, are summarized in Table I. For the entire simulation, it is assumed that
div.formula: ρ s = ρ r = ρ, ε 1 = ε 2 = ε 2,p = ε, and outage threshold C O 1 = C O 2 = C t .
div.p: The close match found between the analytical and simulation results confirms the authenticity of the authors's analysis presented here. For the sake of comparison, simulation results of HD-NOMA-RS and HD-OMA-RS are also presented. The proportional fairness criteria [1], i.e., equal transmission power (P 1 = P 2 = 0.5) and equal bandwidth (β w = 0.5) allocation to each user, are considered for HD-OMA-RS.

div.head: A. Ergodic Capacity
div.p: ESC comparison between FD-NOMA-RS, HD-NOMA-RS and HD-OMA-RS, with respect to (w.r.t) ρ under perfect and imperfect IC, is illustrated in Figs. 2 and3, respectively, with parameters θ 1 =0.6, θ 2 =0.4, θ 3 =0.9, and θ 4 =0.1. From Fig. 2, it is observed that EC of G 2 increases linearly with increase in ρ. On the other hand, EC of G 1 increases slowly in low ρ, but remains nearly constant from medium to high ρ. This is reasonable, because SIC is carried out for G 2 in both uplink and downlink, whereas symbol s 1 , relating to G 1 , is decoded by considering the other symbol as noise. Furthermore, it is clear that FD-NOMA-RS can achieve almost double the capacity of HD-NOMA-RS, and more than that of HD-OMA-RS, under perfect IC. This performance gain has become possible because of exploiting FD strategy in FD-NOMA-RS. From Fig. 3, it is noticed that ESC with κ 1 = κ 2 = 0.02 3 is better than the ESC with κ 1 = κ 2 = 0.04 3 It is also noticed that FD-NOMA-RS can obtain outstanding capacity gains as compared to those of HD-NOMA-RS, under imperfect IC. It is further found that ESC of both FD-NOMA-RS and HD-NOMA-RS saturates in a high ρ regime. In addition, under imperfect SIC and at low to medium ρ, both FD-NOMA-RS and HD-NOMA-RS show significantly better performance than HD-OMA-RS, but at high ρ, the performance gains depend on the level of residual interference. In Fig. 4, ESC of FD-NOMA-RS, HD-NOMA-RS, and HD-OMA-RS (as a benchmark) is depicted w.r.t power allocation factors under perfect IC. Two cases of ρ, where ρ=10 dB and ρ=40 dB are considered. In the top sub-figure, the impact of varying θ 1 and θ 2 , keeping the values for θ 3 (=0.9) and θ 4 (=0.1) fixed, is shown. In the bottom sub-figure, the impact of varying θ 3 and θ 4 , keeping the values for θ 1 (=0.6) and θ 2 (=0.4) fixed, is presented. It is found that power allocation factors in both uplink and downlink have a significant impact on the performance of both FD-NOMA-RS and HD-NOMA-RS.

div.head: B. Outage Probability
div.p: In Fig. 5, OP comparison between HD-NOMA-RS and HD-OMA-RS is presented under imperfect IC with parameters θ 1 =0.65, θ 2 =0.35, θ 3 =0.9, θ 4 =0.1, I s =-20 dB, and κ 1 = κ 2 = 0.02 3 . From this figure, it is found that FD-NOMA-RS shows significantly better outage performance than that of HD-NOMA-RS, for each case. It is also found that OP
div.formula: = 2 C O 1 -1, R t R t +1 < θ 3 < 1 and R 1 t = 2 2C O 1 -1, R 1 t R1
div.p: t +1 < θ 3 < 1, respectively, to choose the target data rate, mentioned in Section IV.

OP comparison between FD-NOMA-RS, HD-NOMA-RS, and HD-OMA-RS w.r.t ρ, is presented in Fig. 7, under perfect IC with parameters θ 1 =0.65, θ 2 =0.35, θ 3 =0.9, θ 4 =0.1, and C t =0.5 bps/Hz. From this figure, it is obvious that FD-NOMA-RS shows significantly better outage performance than that of HD-NOMA-RS, for each case. It is also found that, with the system parameters considered here, G because G 2 gets advantage from SIC performance, in both uplink and downlink. On the contrary, G 1 in FD-NOMA-RS outperforms any user (i.e., G 1 or G 2 ) in HD-OMA-RS at low ρ, but underperforms at medium-to-high ρ, because of the severe interference faced by G 1 with increasing ρ.

Moreover, in Figs. 8 and9, the impact of power allocation factors on OP is demonstrated with parameters ρ=15 dB and C t =0.5 bps/Hz, under perfect IC. Between the two, the impact of varying θ 1 and θ 2 , keeping the values for θ 3 (=0.9) and θ 4 (=0.1) fixed, is demonstrated in Fig. 8, and the impact of varying θ 3 and θ 4 , keeping the values for θ 1 (=0.6) and θ 2 (=0.4) fixed, is demonstrated in Fig. 9. From these figures, it is obvious that power allocation factors (θ 1 , θ 2 ) in uplink have greater impact than the power allocation factors (θ 3 , θ 4 ) in downlink on the performance of FD-NOMA-RS and HD-NOMA-RS. It is to be noted here that, owing to the proportional fairness criteria, both G 1 and G 2 in HD-OMA-RS show almost similar outage behavior. Therefore, in the legends of Figs. 7, 8, and 9, OMA represents either G 1 or G 2 in HD-OMA-RS.

div.head: C. Outage Capacity
div.p: In Fig. 10, 10% OSC of FD-NOMA-RS is plotted with parameter values θ 1 =0.6, θ 2 =0.4, θ 3 =0.9, and θ 4 =0.1. Two cases of I s and κ 1 /κ 2 , where I s =-20 dB, I s =0 dB and κ 1 = κ 2 = 0.02 3 , κ 1 = κ 2 = 0.04 3 are considered here. It is observed that OSC increases linearly with increase in ρ under perfect IC, whereas it saturates in the high ρ regime under imperfect IC, because of severe residual interference. It is further noticed that OSC with κ 1 = κ 2 = 0.02 3 is better than the OSC with κ 1 = κ 2 = 0.04 3 . Moreover, OSC with I s =-20 dB outperforms OSC with I s =0 dB, thus indicating that OSC improves with a better IC technique.

Finally, in Fig. 11, OSC w.r.t the specified OP ε is depicted, with parameter values θ 1 =0.6, θ 2 =0.4, θ 3 =0.9, θ 4 =0.1, I s =0 dB, and κ 1 = κ 2 = 0.02 3 . From this figure, it is found that OSC improves with increase in ε, as expected, as also with increase in ρ.

div.head: VII. CONCLUSION
div.p: In this paper, an FD cooperative relay sharing network, using uplink and downlink NOMA has been proposed and investigated, in which multiple source-destination pairs can share an FD relay. The performance of FD-NOMA-RS is studied in terms of ESC, OP, and OSC, along with analytical derivations. The analytical derivations of OP for HD-NOMA-RS and HD-OMA-RS are also provided. The analytical results are validated by simulations and highlighted the advantages of FD-NOMA-RS over HD-NOMA-RS and HD-OMA-RS. The impact of different system parameters on the performance of FD-NOMA-RS, HD-NOMA-RS and HD-OMA-RS is also studied. The outcome of this study reveals that FD-NOMA-RS holds promise as a potential approach for improving the 5G systems' performance than its counterpart, the halfduplex system. For future research, it is proposed to study a cooperative relay sharing network, using multi-input, multioutput NOMA.

Moreover, OP comparison between G 1 and G 2 in FD-NOMA-RS is demonstrated in Fig.6, under imperfect IC, with parameters θ 1 =0.6, θ 2 =0.4, θ 3 =0.9, θ 4 =0.1, and C t =0.5 bps/Hz. From Figs.5 and 6, it is observed that OP of G 2 decreases linearly in the low-to-moderate ρ regime, but saturates in the high ρ regime. On the other hand, OP of G 1 decreases gradually in the low ρ regime, but remains almost constant in mediumto-high ρ regime. From Fig.6, it is also found that I s , κ 1 , and κ 2 have significant impact on OP of G 2 . It should be noted that FD-NOMA-RS and HD-NOMA-RA must satisfy the conditions R t

div.p: This research was supported by Basic Science Research Program through the National Research Foundation of Korea (NRF) funded by the Ministry of Education (2015R1D1A1A01061075). Md. Fazlul Kader and Soo Young Shin are with the WENS Laboratory,

Dr. Leung has co-authored more than 500 technical papers in international journals and conference proceedings, and several of these papers had been selected for best paper awards. His research interests cover broad areas of wireless networks and mobile systems.
